awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Hardware Acceleration for Zero Knowledge Proofs for Distributed Ledger Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the enablement of verifiable and confidential computing through research and development that improves the performance and cost of the underlying cryptographic computations. Digital services play a foundational role in varied sectors including communication, education, banking, and others. Without cryptography these services would be impossible to conduct online in a secure and private manner. However, many new and more powerful cryptographic techniques remain out of reach due to their computationally expensive nature. Reducing the cost of these operations enables not just secure communication, but also verifiable and confidential computation, of rapidly growing interest to both the enterprise and government segments for use cases such as privacy-preserving machine learning. The market for verifiable and confidential computing solutions is expected to grow to over one billion dollars in the next five years.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to design and develop a high performance cloud-based system for verifiable and confidential computing. Currently many verifiable and confidential computing techniques can not be brought into production due to their computationally expensive nature. This project performs algorithmic research, hardware design, and software development, that will improve the performance and cost of these operations. In particular, this project optimizes cryptographic algorithms to make them more amenable to GPU-based processing, optimize the software implementation of those algorithms to target GPU architectures, devise methods for reducing the amount of data that needs to be transmitted, and develop a scale-out architecture that dynamically scales capacity as the complexity of uses and number of users grow. With the appropriate design, the project expects to develop a system with over an order of magnitude or more performance than existing designs. Furthermore, by creating a ‘cloud-based’ infrastructure, these resources can be made available to developers around the world, with low latency and low cost. The expected improvements in performance, cost, and access will enable new use cases that have previously been impractical.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Zero-knowledge proofs are a cryptographic technique that enables verifiable and confidential computing. Their use is of growing importance to the blockchain industry as they provide a means to scale blockchain transaction throughput and can also enable private blockchain transactions. However, zero-knowledge proofs are computationally expensive resulting in high costs and rendering them impractical for many use cases. The goal of this project’s research was to leverage alternative computing architectures to improve the performance and cost of zero-knowledge proof generation. In particular, this research focused on both commercial off-the-shelf hardware like GPUs and FPGAs, as well as custom developed application specific integrated circuits.

 

To begin the research the team conducted a comprehensive study of zero-knowledge proofs and their use in the blockchain industry. This included an analysis of the most widely used use cases, software libraries, and algorithms in production. From here the team then developed optimized algorithm implementations on a variety of hardware architectures including GPUs and FPGAs. Such algorithms included multi-scalar multiplication and number theoretic transformations. To the best of the team's knowledge, these newly-developed implementations were several times faster than any other implementation available at the time, and offered an order of magnitude better performance per dollar. In fact, one of the developed algorithms was entered into the zPrize initiative and was awarded 1st place, beating out competitors such as Jane Street Capital and Jump Trading.

 

With an understanding of the performance that could be achieved with commercial off-the-shelf hardware, the research team then began to investigate how performance and cost could be improved through the development of an application specific integrated circuit. This research involved developing a hardware architecture that met a number of constraints such as power, bandwidth, and memory limitations. The overall conclusion of this research was that while some algorithms could benefit greatly from a custom circuit, providing over an order of magnitude improvement in performance and cost, other algorithms were fundamentally limited by these constraints and saw smaller improvements in comparison to off-the-shelf hardware.

 

Finally, with optimizations implemented for key zero-knowledge proof algorithms, the team set out to determine how best to deliver these benefits to users and customers. After conducting significant user market research it became clear that most users preferred using computing hardware from cloud providers over deploying their own hardware on premise. Furthermore, some users expressed a preference to have the hardware and zero knowledge proof software managed by a service provider and to access the software through an application programming interface. As a result the research team set out to develop a computing architecture that would enable users to access zero-knowledge proof generation ‘as-a-service’. The developed architecture provides high performance, high availability, and high security by leveraging technologies such as GPUs, Kubernetes, and public-key cryptography. Overall the research conducted by the team was highly successful and resulted in an end product that improved the performance and cost of zero-knowledge proof generation.
